fields.description:
I'm very sorry to dig up an [old issue|BCLOUD-8300], but I would like to ask if, after 4 years, you might reconsider the earlier decision to not support OPTIONS requests.

I believe I have a compelling use case for supporting OPTIONS:

I am a Marketplace vendor, and one of my most popular apps is [Open API Documentation for Confluence|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/net.oharagroup.confluence.plugins.confluence-open-api/cloud/overview].

This is a Confluence macro that takes an Open API (a.k.a. Swagger) JSON/YAML definition, either directly in the macro body or from any URL; and renders API documentation.

*Importantly*: All of this (fetching the URL, rendering the API documentation) occurs _in the client's browser_. A key advantage of this is that the customer's JSON/YAML never passes through my add-on servers; and I, as the app vendor, never sees the customers data.  Customers don't need to be concerned with privacy/security risks of using a 3rd party for their API documentation solution, because their data never leaves their Confluence instance.

Commonly, customers ask if they can store their JSON/YAML definitions in their source code repository of choice (typically GitHub or Bitbucket); rather than hosting the files elsewhere on the web.

For public repositories, this is no problem. Customers can simply specify the "raw" file URL in the macro, e.g. https://bitbucket.org/:project/:repo/raw/:commit/:file , and everything works as expected.

For private repositories, however; the only way (that I'm aware of) to fetch files is via the REST API.

A cross-origin {{GET}} request normally wouldn't trigger CORS, however because requests to the Bitbucket REST API require basic authentication, the presence of the {{Authorization}} header means that browsers must first issue a preflight OPTIONS request as part of the CORS process (to check the {{Access-Control-Allow-*}} response headers).

Without support for OPTIONS in the REST API, browsers are unable to make an authenticated request to fetch files from a private Bitbucket repository.

As a workaround, some of my customers have taken to using a proxy between their user's browsers and BitBucket, that intercepts the OPTIONS request and injects the necessary CORS headers; but this is not practical for most people.

(Please note: [a similar issue|https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/browse/AMKT-19489] exists with the Marketplace transactions API; and in that case the request to add support for OPTIONS is being considered)

Alternatively, if there is another recommended way for browsers to make credentialled requests to Bitbucket for file content without triggering CORS, I would love to hear it.

I'm aware that, historically, OPTIONS has been considered 'insecure'; but often this was only on the grounds that without a specific use case, it is preferable to reduce the attack surface by disabling support.  In 2017, REST APIs and CORS presents a valid case for enabling OPTIONS support, and I'm confident that your security/infrastructure teams would be capable of enabling this without jeopardising overall security of the service.

I very much hope you will reconsider your stance on this.
fields.summary: Please revisit the decision not to support OPTIONS in the REST API

fields.description:
It would be incredible if we could name the cache based off of the hash of the contents of a file. Primarily because if the file doesn't change then the hash will be the same, therefore we know there is no need to update the cache as well is if we should retrieve the cache.

For example:\\
Say I have a package.json that contains a list of js dependencies for my project. At the beginning of the pipeline there is a check that hashes the contents of my package.json and if it matches any of my caches then it will pull it down. Otherwise cache won't be pulled down and on completion of a pipeline a new cache will be created.

As a result we ensure we always have the proper dependencies and potentially speed up the pipeline as well.

To solve the problem of potential lingering cache we can delete cache that was using this method after a given period of time like a week or two.
fields.summary: Name cache by the hash of a file

fields.description:
Here's a transcript from my terminal:

hg push --new-branch -r tip ssh://hg@bitbucket.org/cameron_simpson/css\\
pushing to ssh://hg@bitbucket.org/cameron_simpson/css\\
searching for changes\\
remote: abort: abandoned transaction found!\\
remote: (run 'hg recover' to clean up transaction)\\
abort: stream ended unexpectedly (got 0 bytes, expected 4)

Please repair this. It would be useful if we could repair this kind of thing ourselves.

Thanks, Cameron Simpson
fields.summary: my repo says: remote: abort: abandoned transaction found!

fields.description:
I noticed in your API documentation at: [https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/api/2/reference/resource/repositories/%7Busername%7D/%7Brepo_slug%7D/pipelines_config/variables/|https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/api/2/reference/resource/repositories/%257Busername%257D/%257Brepo_slug%257D/pipelines_config/variables/] that there is supposed to be a resource for setting variables for pipelines.

When trying to access this endpoint, however, I get a "Resource not found" error. Is this endpoint supposed to be functional?

* 

Our use case is that we are trying to persist data between pipeline builds that can be modified during the build itself. e.g. incrementing a version with each manual deployment.
fields.summary: API - Pipelines - Variables: Resource Not Found

fields.summary: Internal server error when Jenkins tries to fetch branches

fields.description:
Around 90% of the time cloning a <20MB repository takes in excess of three minutes for us, transferring at most three objects per second. This is appalling when compared to competing services such as GitHub, where clones of 500MB repositories complete in under two minutes.

When will Atlassian ops pull their heads out of the sand, acknowledge that there's a serious reliability and performance issue here and communicate what they're doing about it?

Bitbucket breaks our workflow badly enough that we'll be moving to a better service early next year unless Atlassian starts fulfilling its responsibilities to its _*paying*_ customers.
fields.summary: Appalling clone performance, frequent failures

fields.description:
For our project we would like to configure Pipelines to run a specific testsuite for Pull Requests only. Not on just any commit.

Would this be a possibility?
fields.summary: Pipeline configuration for Pull Requests

fields.description:
Please allow --privileged flag to build multiarch docker images.\\
According to this article, it is possible with Github + Travis :\\
http://blog.hypriot.com/post/setup-simple-ci-pipeline-for-arm-images/

Register qemu-*-static for all supported processors except the current one\\
docker run --rm --privileged multiarch/qemu-user-static:register

Currently, the following error is return when running the pipeline:

* docker run --rm --privileged multiarch/qemu-user-static:register --reset\\
docker: Error response from daemon: authorization denied by plugin pipelines: Command not supported.\\
See 'docker run --help'.

Thanks
fields.summary: Allow building multi-architecture Docker images (e.g. ARM images)

fields.description:
I have a Project on BitBucket, and the project has a private source code repository in addition to a public "issues" repository. I don't want users to be able to see source code, but I do want them to be able to file their own issues about the project, hence the separate repos.

It would be nice to be able to close an issue by committing something like {{Fixes teamname/issuerepo#issue}} to the source repo. Currently, the commit message just contains a link to that repo, but the issue itself is not linked.

Another solution would be to have a way to designate an "issues repo" for any particular source repo, so committing {{Fixes BCLOUD-10}} would close Issue 10 on the "issues" repo (this, of course, would require that the source repo not have issue tracking enabled on itself).

This would also allow multiple source repos to share the same issue tracker.

EDIT: I see now that "Public Issue Tracker" is an option for a private repository (this wasn't available when I first created the repo a while ago), but this proposal could still allow cross-repo issue closing (which GitHub already supports) as well as a shared issue tracker for multiple source repos.
fields.summary: Close issues with a commit from a separate repository
CommentService.addReply() doesn't add a reply, doesn't throw exception

fields.description:
In the commit view page of Mercurial repositories, obsoleted commits always show "default" as own named branch, regardless of actual one.\\
This can be reproduced by steps below with enabling changeset evolution.

# make a commit on a named branch "FOO"
# push the new commit to the repository on Bitbucket cloud
# rebase this commit to another named branch "BAR"
# push the rebased commit to the repository on Bitbucket cloud
# visit "commits" page of the commit made at (1), which is already obsoleted at (3)

Obsoleted commits are never be pull-ed any more, and never appear in main history pages. Therefore, this is minor (or trivial ?) bug, but might confuse users.
fields.summary: Obsoleted commits show "default" as own named branch, regardless of actual one (BBCC-502)

Thanks

fields.description:
In a Pull Request, if a commit gets removed when a PR is updated, it does not show which commits were removed instead it shows only the new commits.

It would be nice if PR's could show which commits were removed from the PR after the latest update.
fields.summary: Show Removed Commits when PR gets updated

fields.summary: HTTP 500: "$userCount" evaluates to undefined

fields.description: Trying to fire up a pipeline for the first time, via the web UI. I entered "image: vfunction/cppjava" to get a custom image, failure with no log. Eventually (after try without the custom image and trying the base image of the custom image), I realized it was looking for vfunction/cppjava:latest, when all I had there was vfunction/cppjava:0.1a, but this was a pretty frustrating first-time experience.
fields.summary: pipeline fails and log is empty when image does not exist

fields.description:
The pipeline is failed but there aren't any error messages and the log is empty.

*Update:*\\
Now the pipeline is running successfully without any changes just re-run.
fields.summary: Pipilene is failed but the log is empty

fields.description: Users without write access have no recourse to resolve the repo size issue (and are probably not affected by it, either), so we should stop showing it to those users.
fields.summary: Only show repo size warning to users with write access

fields.description:
While reviewing a Pull Request and going over PR guidelines for a particular repository or project it was possible to create tasks on the PR directly from the Pull Request guidelines.

!1016379315-Capture.PNG|thumbnail!

Now the "+" button does nothing while a few months ago it was working an a task could be created directly associated to one of the notes from the guidelines.

!3725609054-Capture.PNG|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Cannot create tasks directly from Pull Request guidelines

fields.description:
We see more and more that we do our best to do documentation but that font is causing really weird situations.

Things like a simple word like classes can look like dasses if you read it with the current selected font. I would suggest using a True Type font for the md file that available on most systems and OSes. At this moment it can be very confusing if someone makes good documentations.
fields.summary: Change default font for the Markdown output

fields.description:
Hi,

My repository is linked with a Jenkins instance for CI and CD, and there is a hook to call the build each push and retrieve the build status.

The problem is that in some cases, as the image, the branch in bitbucket is linked with a status of the other branch, which can do the reviewer take wrong decisions.

Why does it happen?
fields.summary: Incorrect Build Status

fields.description:
Cloning "git@bitbucket.org:KarthikManikanta/wishmessage.git" ... error: build error: Warning: Permanently added 'bitbucket.org,104.192.143.1' (RSA) to the list of known hosts. Permission denied (publickey). fatal: Could not read from remote repository. Please make sure you have the correct access rights and the repository exists.

IN openshift
fields.summary: bitbucket cannot access publickey from openshift 3

fields.description:
The current pipeline scheduling is way too blunt.

It should be more of a pure cron (it's probably that underneath anyway) like Jenkins does it.
fields.summary: Advanced scheduled Pipelines via cron expressions

fields.description:
Running fastlane in Pipelines, and fastlane's {{get_version_number}} uses Apple's agvtool to get the current version # from iTunes Connect.

It's failing because it cannot find agvtool on the Pipeline machines.

I get this error:

{code}
Exit status of command 'cd /opt/atlassian/pipelines/agent/build && agvtool what-marketing-version -terse' was 127 instead of 0.
sh: 1: agvtool: not found
{code}

How do I make sure this is added? I've already included {{gem "xcode-install"}} in my gemfile.

Gemfile:

{code}
source "https://rubygems.org"

gem "fastlane"
gem "cocoapods"
gem "badge"
gem "xcode-install"
{code}
fields.summary: agvtool Not Found

fields.description: Menu items from the Dropdown-menu component now have role="menuitem" on them, which is taking them out of the link-list that NVDA creates.  They now show up under form elements instead of links.
fields.summary: Drop down sub menu's are not recognized properly by screen readers. (BBCDEV-8488)

fields.description:
Commits window shows commits timestamps as dates and for recent commits it is even worse - as "N days ago". You can see the very same date or even "N days ago" if you click on particular commit.

It is too ambiguous for serious dynamically maintained multi-branched projects.

I would suggest to *show commit timestamps* in the commits page and in the page for particular commit *as date with minute granularity*

PS: User can see exact commit time as UTC with up to second precision in "View raw commit", but this is too far down the user interface and by venturing outside of the BitBucket GUI (this is what "raw" actually asserts"
fields.summary: Give exact time of the commits

fields.description:
There isn't that much else to say. I've added a screenshot that shows the error screen and also the network requests in the Firefox developer tools. You can clearly see the POST request for executing the merge (fulfill), followed by a GET request for the status. You can see the data of the response in the right bottom panel. {{complete}} is set to {{true}}, and the {{error}} array is empty:

!93412926-bitbucket-screenshot.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: [Mercurial] Squashing a pull-request results in an error without message (BBCC-503)

fields.description:
Starting from yesterday i'm getting the error when the number of services per step exceeds 2:

"We only support 3 services (including docker) in each step. Please limit the number of services specified against any step in your bitbucket-pipelines.yml to fix the error."

But the number of services in my yml is 3 per step, and it worked before. Do you guys know what's going on?
fields.summary: Pipeline stoped working for 3 services per step

fields.description:
When we are going to create PR, diff isn't loaded, and PR cannot be created.\\
We have detected this issue several months ago. This bug is critical due to we aren't able to deploy a critical hot fix.

More info can be located in attachment file.

Thanks in advance.

error: build error: Warning: Permanently added 'bitbucket.org,104.192.143.1' (RSA) to the list of known hosts.\\

Please make sure you have the correct access rights\\
and the repository exists.

fields.description: We have somehow arrived at a situation where a newer version of an npm dependency has been installed and cached. We are investigating how this occurred, but for now, a fix would be to manually delete the cache, but there does not seem to be a way to do this. Clicking on the "Caches" button on the pipelines main page says that we haven't set up any caches yet, even though there is a cache line in bitbucket-pipelines.yml.
fields.summary: Implement way to clear pipelines dependency caches

fields.description:
It would be great if you added Gherkin syntax (from HipTest) markup (both in code and in the pull request notes). It's very simple and human-readable.

https://docs.hiptest.net/writing-scenarios-with-gherkin-syntax/
fields.summary: Gherkin Syntax Support

fields.description:
Cannot run git fetch and pull ssh.\\
Giving an error:** Could not resolve hostname bitbucket.org: Name or service not known fatal: Could not read from remote repository.\\
Please make sure you have the correct access rights and the repository exists.**\\
I did ping bitbucket.org returns the same error "*ping: bitbucket.org: Name or service not known*"\\
I restarted the server but still can't get working. Any idea?

This is happening on my production server, and holding me back from getting my job done. Any help on this is much appreciated.
fields.summary: Fatal error:  bitbucket.org: Name or service not known

fields.description: .vue files is the subset of html+js, so when trying to make a snippet that is *.vue, you are unable to specify this as the correct format-- switching to JavaScript will change extension to *.js

fields.description: It would be great to have an option to turn on email notifications for success builds in Bitbucket Pipelines, specially if you are using it for CI and you don't want to be in front of the Pipelines page to see if you build is passing or not.
fields.summary: Email notification for successful pipelines

fields.description:
There have already been three other requests for this feature but the primary one, [8271|BCLOUD-8271] was closed due to inactivity. Combined there are 25 votes and watches including myself. This seems like a simple feature to implement and would be incredibly helpful. I am opening up this new one in hope that Atlassian will finally implement the feature that would help myself as well as many others considerably on a daily basis.

One of my responsibilities is to review all pull requests which range from 3 to 15 per day. While in the Pull Request Overview page I would like the ability to copy the branch name similar to that in the repository browse view. This would make it much easier to copy the name so that checking out the branch locally to test can be done more quickly and without errors.

Presently my methodology is to select the text on the page but more often than not the branch name is ellipses or extraneous text is included and when pasted in shell, caused errors.

Attached is a mockup of the feature.

Related tickets:

* Ticket [8271|BCLOUD-8271] 4 votes & 9 watchers
* Ticket [9574](Link URL) 5 watchers
* Ticket [11280](Link URL) 2 votes & 4 watchers
fields.summary: Add ability to copy the branch name or url to checkout a branch from a Pull Request Overview

fields.description:
We are experiencing this issue at random with PR of ~50 files, with ~4K line additions, and ~1K line deletions. Refreshing the page sometimes fixes it.

We've been able to load significantly larger PR's in the past, albeit with poor page performance. Page performance is not an issue in this case once the diff is loaded.
fields.summary: Random "This merge is too large to display" errors

fields.description: If a user deletes a repository from Bitbucket that is linked to a board, currently the integration service doesn't seem to know the repo has been deleted.  This then causes empty responses when trying to work with Trello boards when they are reaching out to Bitbucket.
fields.summary: Deleting a repo that is linked to a Trello board breaks the integration. (BBCC-259)

fields.description: Hi, i cannot pull or push to the repository, i have installed the latest version of source tree, but cannot permit made push or pull, am re installed and replace to  old version for windows and nothing, can you help me, please?
fields.summary: Cannot pull / push

When I try to push some commits to the private repository B1985, I get a "remote: abort: abandoned transaction found!" error.

It seems, you have to do a "hg recover" in your server to fix the issue.

Thanks in advance\\
Quentin

fields.description:
When referencing a pull request from a commit message the entire "pull request #number" will output as a link :\\
!1508332079-Screenshot-2017-11-27%20tylto%20tylto-api%20Commits%20%E2%80%94%20Bitbucket.png|thumbnail!\\
However when referencing an issue from a commit message only the "#number" will output as a link :\\
!2895996678-Screenshot-2017-11-27%20tylto%20tylto-api%20Commits%20%E2%80%94%20Bitbucket.png|thumbnail!\\
I suggest that it always behaves the same as for the pull request references. The entire "object name #number" would output as a link.

pushing to ssh://hg@bitbucket.org/yatahaze/tmtsarbomba

I have a feeling this isn't something I can fix?

fields.description:
I believe a "collapse file" button will come in handy when you're checking changes in files in the diff revision. Before hitting "Create pull request"

Sometimes they're too many files and changes and scrolling is painful.

Developers' metacarpal tunnel will thank you for this.
fields.summary: Pull request diff revision: on the fly collapse files changed

fields.description: Several months ago, when I edited the readme on bitbucket, there was a toolbar which is useful to add links and pictures. Now I want to edit the readme again, but I found the toolbar is missing and I could not find a way to enable it.
fields.summary: Re-enable the toolbar for edit readme (Markdown)(BBS-67934)

fields.description:
If I create a pull request from a branch with a {{<>}} in it's name, the pull request hangs.\\
Only using {{<}} or {{>}}, or using it in reverse order doesn't hang the PR. But the branch name {{<foo>}} hangs as well.\\
It sounds like it has something to do with sanitising the branch name.

The hanging is similar to issue BCLOUD-7371 and BCLOUD-5837.

It's a minor issue, since there is an easy workaround (don't use {{<>}} in the branch name).
fields.summary: Pull request hangs on using `<>`

fields.description: To help PR reviewers, it would be great, if a PR author could order the files, so they could be read in the easiest to understand way. E.g. if you introduce a new class, it would be great, if readers would see that class BEFORE other code that starts using the class.
fields.summary: Allow PR author to arrange files in a good reading order

fields.description:
It would be super nice if the currently running step was visible whilst its scrolling.

We have some super long running steps that can all look pretty similar just from their output.

Something like, if the current line was {{position: sticky}} above the logs.
fields.summary: Pipelines should show the currently running step somewhere

The new "trigger: manual" is great but we would only be able to use it if there was an option for the step to be visible if the user is an administrator.

I would like to see a "role" keyword added and you can assign a group to the keyword (ex: role: administrator), or maybe even a user.

fields.description:
From BCLOUD-15031

Today, the "minimum successful builds" branch permission also requires no failed builds.

Some teams would prefer the "no failed builds" requirement to be optional - hence this issue.
fields.summary: Split "no failed builds" requirement into its own branch permission

fields.description:
In the output of our pipelines, consistently the letter {{a}} gets replaced by one of our environment variables,  {{$REPO_MAGENTO_COM_MCT_USER}}.

!377478479-Pasted%20image%20at%202017_11_21%2009_40%20AM.png|thumbnail!

This causes the output of pipelines to become unreadable.
fields.summary: Pipelines output incorrectly expands environment variables

fields.description:
When using the online editor to make a quick fix - and the file contains a non-ASCII value, e.g. Danish letters: æøå - the file will be stored in iso-8859-1 as opposed to UTF-8, which can botch the buildability of a project.

There are several ways to remedy this:

# don't use the online editor
# git chekout - convert file to UTF-8 - commit and push
# only use ASCII values

But none of these seem attractive when the online editor exists.
fields.summary: Unicode vs. online editor

fields.summary: test

Can access menu <Repo>/Settings/Webhooks

fields.summary: Poor mobile support for bb.org

fields.description:
When integrating Bitbucket with JIRA, some users may select only a few repositories from a certain team/account in JIRA DVCS accounts page.

Selecting 'Create branch' from a JIRA issue takes you to Bitbucket and the dropdown 'Repository' shows all repos the user has access to. Some users would like to see only the repos they have configured in JIRA DVCS accounts page.
fields.summary: When creating a branch from JIRA I want to see only the repositories configured in DVCS accounts

fields.description:
Short and simple:

This does not work: [https://bitbucket.org/snippets/sg6|https://bitbucket.org/snippets/sg6]

This does work: [https://bitbucket.org/snippets/sg6/|https://bitbucket.org/snippets/sg6/]

The slash in the end makes the difference. Linking to the snippets' pages are correct on the whole website; error only occurs when manually entering the link (without slash in the end). Thus the issue has lowest priority.
fields.summary: User's Snippets Page shows 404 when missing trailing slash

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When a project contains public repositories and/or a public issue tracker/wiki in its repos, the following message appears in the Project Settings and the user is prevented from making the project private:\\
!3088422543-Screen%20Shot%202017-11-20%20at%2011.21.55.png|thumbnail!

The message above doesn't specify which are the public repos or the repos containing a public issue tracker/wiki, so an admin will have to check them one by one.

h3. Suggested Solution
Include in this page (or possibly in a message shown when the user attempts to make the project private) a list the public repos or the repos containing a public issue tracker/wiki.

h3. Why this is important
For projects containing a large number of repos, it can be time consuming to check all repo/issue tracker/wiki settings one by one. Showing a list will allow the admin to immediately fix (make private) the ones needed.
fields.summary: When setting a Project as private, show which repos are public or contain a public issue tracker/wiki

fields.description:
Hi, i would like that only a couple of person on the team can accept and thus merge pull request. If i set those person in the "Merge via pull request" under "Branch permission", all the other developer will have a "permission denied" when trying to create a pull request.

Pull request is created by SourceTree; if i grant "Merge via pull request" permission to the user, then he can create (and accept) the pull request.
fields.summary: Pull request permission vs merge pull request permission

fields.description: We set up the minimum number of approval to 1, then we create a pull request and try to merge it without any approval, and the merge was executed successful.
fields.summary: Minimum approval number is not respected

fields.description:
I have a repo called "mownah_cloud_build_deploy" that failed import from my instance Bitbucket Server. Whenever I try to access it in order to delete it, I get the message "repository unavailable". All I want to do is delete the repository and try to import it again.

https://bitbucket.org/smwhteam/mownah_cloud_build_deploy/

Is there any way I can resolve this issue?
fields.summary: Repository unavailable - I need to try again...

fields.description:
In pipelines multi step, each step will run a "Build Setup" which will clone and checkout the repository. In scenarios, while the first step is in progress, the branch is deleted. The following step will fail at the "Build Setup" as the clone will fail due to the branch does not exist any longer.

It would be good if we can cache the initial clone & checkout to be used in subsequent steps. This could also help with the duration of the build.
fields.summary: Cache Cloned and checkout repository in Pipelines Multi step

fields.description:
Currently, Pipelines does not wait until all declared services are up and running before the build execution starts. As a result, a build could fail because a service container was not fully started yet (e.g. a test failed because a database service container had not fully started).

Maybe this should be an optional configurable setting in the YML? This might require user input to define when a service container is considered to be 'ready'.

*Edit:* this wait is already implemented for Docker and auth proxy services. 
h4. Workaround

In the meantime you can do this yourselves by adding an initial step to your pipeline that waits for the service to be ready, e.g. poll for 200 OK, before allowing the remaining steps to run.
fields.summary: Build execution should wait until all services are ready

fields.description:
When enable email notifications for repositories, user will received notifications on commits being done in all branches.

User would like to have branch information stored in the email notification when a commit is done for a specific branch.\\
This is so that users can create a filter to ignore commits being made from a specific branch.
fields.summary: Provide specific branch information for email notifications

fields.description:
We have some pull requests that show up in the list view that there are unresolved pull request tasks. However, when you enter the pull request it shows that all of the pull requests are complete. This doesn't happen all the time.

This seems to more frequently happen when the pull request task was on a portion of code that was hidden after an update to the pull request. Upon viewing the task you can still see it was checked off in both the pull request task dropdown and by clicking the comment bubble on the file in the pull request to see the original comment and task.

This issue basically leaves some pull requests sitting longer than they should because people think there is still work to be done so they do not review. Basically this makes pull request tasks unusable at all for us.

This is happening for us on Bitbucket Cloud.
fields.summary: Pull request list view showing incomplete pull request tasks when all pull request tasks have actually been completed.
